questions.text: In a woman having a previous history of cesarean section all of the following are contraindications of VBAC, except:
All are the contraindications for vaginal birth after previous caesarean except:

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of inverted “T” shaped uterine incision

options.label: D
options.text: Where facilities for emergency caesareans are not available

questions.correct_answer: B. Previous lower segment transverse caesarean

questions.text: In classical ceasrean section more chanced of rupture of uterus is in:
A lady with previous CS presents in labour. Trial of scar is contraindicated in all except:

options.label: A
options.text: H/O previous LSCs due to malpresentation

options.label: B
options.text: Knowing the fact that the previous CS was due to CPD

questions.correct_answer: A. H/O previous LSCs due to malpresentation

questions.text: A 33-yrs-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks' gestation, presents for her routine prenatal care. She delivered her first baby by cesarean section due to nonreassuring fetal heart rate pattern on the fetal monitor. Her second baby was delivered by cesarean section also because she did not want a trial of labor. Both infants weighed less than 4000 g and are doing fine now. You obtain operative records of her cesarean sections, which show one Pfannenstiel skin incision and one classical type of incision of the uterus. Currently, she is interested in vaginal delivery. What is the best advice you can give her?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaginal delivery is not recommended because the risk of uterine rupture approaches 8%

options.label: B
options.text: Vaginal delivery is recommended because the risk of uterine rupture is less than 1%

options.label: C
options.text: Vaginal delivery is not contraindicated with a history of two previous cesarean sections

options.label: D
options.text: Vaginal delivery is a possibility, but risk of rupture is between 0.5% and 4%

questions.correct_answer: A. Vaginal delivery is not recommended because the risk of uterine rupture approaches 8%

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation had a myomectomy for infertility previously. While pushing during the second stage of labor, she is noted to have fetal bradycardia associated with some vaginal bleeding. The fetal head, which was previously at +2 station, is now noted to be at –3 station. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Following a cesarean birth, contraindications for a trial of labor in a subsequent pregnancy include

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that the first section was for cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD)

questions.text: You are counselling a 24-year-old woman who is a G2P1 at 36 weeks gestation. She delivered her ?rst baby at 41 weeks gestation by caesarean section as a result of fetal distress that occurred during an induction of labor for mild preeclampsia. She would like to know if she can have a trial of labor with this pregnancy. Which of the following is the best response to this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: No, since she has never had a vaginal delivery.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, but only if she had a low transverse caesarean section.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because once she has had a caesarean section she must deliver all of her subsequent children by caesarean section.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if her uterine incision was made above the lower uterine segment.

questions.correct_answer: B. Yes, but only if she had a low transverse caesarean section.
